content.text: The water barrel contains \(0.050 \text{m}^3\) of pure water. The density of pure water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\)
Calculate the mass of pure water in the barrel
mass of water =   .........  \(kg\)

The density of sea water is \(1030 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\). The density of the plastic is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\). Use this information and the information in **(a)** to state and explain whether the full barrel will float in sea water
statement
explanation
Fig. 1.1 shows a plastic water barrel. The barrel is full of water
State the student who has chosen the correct movement for one period of a pendulum
student
Another student uses a stopwatch to measure the time taken for 50 periods of a pendulum. Fig. 2.2 shows the time taken on the stopwatch
Calculate the time for one period of the pendulum. Give your answer to 3 significant figures
time for one period =   .........  s
The student measures the displacement of the pendulum bob from its rest position. The displacement is \(16.5 \text{cm}\), as shown in Fig. 2.3
State the displacement in millimetres
displacement =   .........  mm

Four students P, Q, R and S each attempt to measure the time period (the time for one complete oscillation) of a pendulum. The arrows in Fig. 2.1 show the movements of the pendulum that each student times
Describe how a student can determine the extension of the spring. You may draw on Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2 as part of your answer
Determine the extension produced by a load of 7.5 N
extension =   .........  \(cm\)
Determine the load that would produce an extension of 10.0 cm
The student plots a graph of load against extension, as shown in Fig. 3.3
Calculate the mass that has a weight of 6.0 N
Fig. 3.1 shows a spring with no load attached. Fig. 3.2 shows the same spring with a load attached
Fig. 3.2
The tractor has a heavy weight at the front. Explain why the heavy weight is needed
Fig. 4.2 represents the weight of the device and its distance from the pivot
Calculate the moment of the weight of the device about the pivot. State the unit
moment =
Fig. 4.3 shows a tractor fitted with narrow tyres and the same tractor fitted with wide tyres
Explain why wide tyres are more suitable for the tractor on soft soil
Fig. 4.1 shows a tractor fitted with a device for breaking up soil in a field
Here are some statements about energy and energy resources
Some statements are correct. Put a tick \((\checkmark)\) in the box alongside each of these
Building hydroelectric power stations has an impact on the environment
Burning fossil fuels produces atmospheric pollution
Wind turbines are turned using gravitational potential energy
Coal and crude oil are sources of renewable energy
Geothermal energy is obtained from hot rocks below the ground
On Fig. 6.1:
1. Continue the ray of light from the golfer towards the upper mirror of the periscope
2. Draw and label the normal at the point where the ray strikes the mirror
On Fig. 6.1, continue the ray of light after reflection at the upper mirror until it leaves the periscope
State the law of reflection used to deduce the position of the ray of light after striking the mirrors
Fig. 6.2 shows three rays of red light each entering a semi-circular glass block

angle of incidencedescription
Xless than the critical angle

content.text: Using the information in Table 6.1, draw on Fig. 6.2 to complete the path of each ray of red light.
Fig. 6.1 shows a mirror periscope. The periscope is used to view a golfer over the heads of other people. The periscope has two plane mirrors each at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\) to the vertical
(not to scale)
The lens forms an image of object OX
On Fig. 7.1, draw another ray from X to locate the position of the image
On Fig. 7.1, draw an arrow to represent the image of OX and label it I
On Fig. 7.1, mark a principal focus for the lens and label it F
On Fig. 7.1, measure and record the focal length of the lens
focal length =   .........  \(cm\)
Describe the image I
Choose words from the list. Tick \((\checkmark)\) two boxes
An object, OX, is placed in front of a converging lens
Fig. 7.1 shows a ray of light from the object passing through the lens
State how the tuning fork produces the sound
Complete the following sentence. Choose a word from the box
A sound wave is
A loudspeaker produces a sound with a frequency of \(25\mathrm{kHz}\)
A student with healthy ears cannot hear this sound. Explain why
Fig. 8.1 shows a student listening to the sound produced by a tuning fork
The air particles are moving. On Fig. 8.2, draw **two** arrows in opposite directions to show the movement of the air particles
Use Fig. 8.2 to determine the wavelength of the sound wave
wavelength =   .........  \(cm\)
Fig. 8.2 represents a sound wave travelling in air
(drawn full size)
Describe a method of using water waves to demonstrate refraction
The student places a bar magnet on a piece of paper, as shown in Fig. 9.1
Show the pattern of magnetic field lines around the bar magnet
Draw **two** lines above the magnet and **two** lines below the magnet. Start and finish each line at a pole. Include **one** arrow to show the direction of the magnetic field.
The student rubs a plastic rod with a dry cloth. The plastic rod becomes positively charged
Explain why the friction between the plastic and the cloth causes the plastic to become positively charged
The student investigates the forces between two pairs of objects
Fig. 9.2 and Fig. 9.3 show the pairs of objects
State whether there is a force of attraction, a force of repulsion, or no force between the pairs of objects. Draw a **ring** around **one** phrase for each pair of objects
1. two positively charged spheres
Fig. 9.2
force of attraction force of repulsion no force
2. a bar magnet and a bar of copper metal
Fig. 9.3
force of attraction force of repulsion no force
A student is experimenting with magnets and electric charges
To determine the resistance of the lamp, the teacher adds two meters to her circuit
On Fig. 10.1, draw circuit symbols to show each meter correctly connected in the circuit
When the current in the lamp is 0.25A, the potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp is 4.5V. Calculate the resistance of the lamp
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
State the name of component X
Describe and explain how the teacher uses component X to investigate the resistance of the lamp
A teacher is investigating the resistance of a lamp
Fig. 10.1 shows part of the circuit she uses. The circuit is incomplete
Describe an experiment, using any standard laboratory equipment, to demonstrate electromagnetic induction. You may draw a diagram
State the name of a suitable material for the core of the transformer
Explain how the diagram in Fig. 11.1 shows a step-up transformer
Using the information in Fig. 11.1, calculate the output voltage of the transformer
output voltage =   .........  V
Fig. 11.1 shows a transformer connected to an input voltage of \(12\mathrm{V a.c.}\)
A student is experimenting with electromagnetic effects
In the first experiment the count rate for a sample of a radioactive isotope is measured every 30 seconds for 6 minutes
The results are shown in Table 12.1
Estimate the half-life of the radioactive isotope. Use the information in the table
half-life =   .........  minutes
In the second experiment the teacher repeats the procedure with another sample of the same radioactive isotope. The mass of the second sample is greater than that of the first sample
Suggest a value for the count rate for this sample at the start of the experiment
count rate =   .........  counts/second
the nature of an \(\alpha\) -particle
the ionising ability of an \(\alpha\) -particle
the penetrating ability of an \(\alpha\) -particle
One type of particle emitted during radioactive decay is an \(\alpha\) -particle (alpha particle)
Describe:
A teacher carries out two experiments at the same time
